text.p: Lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their Thursday editions. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The death of Juras Adomavicius, head of Kaunas volunteer defence force, in a car explosion last Friday, sparkled off a political row in Vilnius. Opposition leader Ceslovas Jursenas accused country's defence minister of covering up information about terrorist acts which Adamovicius had sent to the minister a few days before his death.
- Vilnius court started hearings of Henrikas Daktaras case, the suspected leader of Kaunas gangland, with the verdict expected next week.

- The government intends to compensate up to 80 percent of deposits to the inhabitants accumulated in the bank accounts before February 26, 1991, said Lithuanian prime minister Gediminas Vagnorius in a radio interview.
- Turnover of the National stock exchange reached 138,8 billion litas in January.
- Lithuanian prime minister says energy tarriffs will grow this year but preceded by an increase of salaries and pensions.
- GEC Alsthom intends to participate in the privatisation of Lithuanian energy sector enterprises.

- Lithuania still undecided on the candidate to the prosecutor general post. President Algirdas Brazauskas suggested Arturas Paulauskas, the current deputy prosecutor general, with the majority Homeland Union parliament faction insisting on their candidate.
- Homeland Union, Christian Democrats and Centre Union intend to create a coalition in Vilnius municipality after March 23 elections.
